text: Disruption of a GATA motif in the <extra_id_0> Duffy <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene promoter abolishes erythroid gene expression in <extra_id_0> Duffy <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - negative individuals .

The mRNA for the <extra_id_0> Duffy <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> blood group antigen , the erythrocyte receptor for the Plasmodium vivax malaria parasite , has recently been cloned and shown to encode a widely expressed chemokine receptor .

Here , we show that the <extra_id_0> Duffy antigen/chemokine receptor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene ( <extra_id_0> DARC <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) is composed of a single exon and that most <extra_id_0> Duffy <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - negative blacks carry a silent <extra_id_0> FY*B <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> allele with a single T to C substitution at nucleotide -46 .
This mutation impairs the promoter activity in erythroid cells by disrupting a binding site for the <extra_id_0> GATA1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> erythroid transcription factor .

With the recent characterization of the <extra_id_0> FY*A <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> FY*B <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> alleles , these findings provide the molecular basis of the <extra_id_0> Duffy <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> blood group system and an explanation for the erythroid - specific repression of the <extra_id_0> DARC <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene in <extra_id_0> Duffy <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - negative individuals .
